comment: If you've never coded before, I don't recommend her. She begins the semester as if everyone knows how to code which is not true. The homework/projects/labs are all straight forward, but her inconsistent grading drove me up the wall. Get the textbook since her tests are open-book.

She is the toughest grader I have ever had. I was only able to squeak out a 85 average on my labs while my friends were getting 98's for the same work with other professors. The midterm and final count for 50% of your grade. Oh, did I mention that the average for the midterm was a 40-something? Yeah, DO NOT TAKE HER unless you enjoy failure lol.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Everything is open book. Even the quizzes and labs. She is, however, a super tough grader and expects excellence especially if you have an open book.

If youre good at computer stuff, youll be fine. I am not, and it was difficult. She has a lot of grades that go into your final grade. Didn't do so well on the tests but the labs, projects, and homework made up for it. She grades pretty easily, just answer and youll get partial credit. Her lectures are pretty dry and boring. The tests are open book

Prof. Pierce is amazing. She's not located in state, but she's extremely interactive in the course. She gave us her phone number and (long) hours and lets us text/call when we need help. Reads all assignments and gives feedback. She's also very encouraging and really wants us to succeed. I did not need the textbook.

She clearly knows her material. Explains it very clearly and she knows which topics are harder, so she'll spend extra time on class. Lab every week, projects due once ever 2 or 3 weeks and 3 open book tests. Lots of work but good for keeping up your average. Great teacher.

Professor Pierce is a very good lecturer. She is usually able to explain things in a way that makes sense to most people, but it all comes straight from the textbook. The lab assignments are very helpful in understanding the material, and the projects will test you, but are easy enough if you apply yourself. Tests are open book.
